review_title: Slow paced, not good for career growth and learning
pros: Mastercard is good for people who want to coast in a job for 5-10 years or more. The work life balance is great because expectations are minimal and people move slowly.
cons:
The company is not set up for career progression. There are tons of people who have been at the company 10+ years and coast in mid-level management. This creates a stagnant environment where you can't learn from teammates and there is limited innovation. In general, people operate in the mindset of "it's not my job." 

Promotions are slow (about 2-3 years for Manager level and below; 3-5 years for Director level; and sometimes longer for Vice Presidents). There is no clear promotion criteria and no formal system for annual career reviews. For example, your manager writes a ~2 paragraph performance review once a year but they're not required to collect 360 feedback from your colleagues. There's also no opportunity to give upward feedback to your manager. 

Like many big organizations, Mastercard is highly political. As a result, senior leadership can be hit or miss. Many SVPs are figureheads that don't know their business well and don't have the expertise to support their team. Leaders are not rewarded for good management; rather, they are rewarded for executive visibility. It's all about who you know and how well you can sell an idea (versus actually achieving a goal).

review_title: Nice Place to Work, but am concerned about woke response to Covid vaccination status.
pros: I've been at Mastercard for a while and have always found the culture here quite respectful. People are friendly, nice to work with and I've almost never had any incidents that have concerned me, until now, with Covid.
cons:
Mastercard has sent employees emails - first to encourage people to confirm their 'vaccination' status, then demanding that they confirm and upload their vaccination status to Workday. Now I see alerts telling me to confirm my 'booster' status and veiled passive-aggressive threats that this request is 'currently voluntary'. This approach was the same when they asked for, and then subsequently demanded the initial status and proof. And they use ambiguous ridiculous language like - "this will help inform our response to the pandemic." Serious question - if your data gathering demands showed that 20% were 'vaccinated' or '80%' were 'vaccinated', how would that change your response??? I find this all highly offensive, even moreso as they organized a video session before where they had a doctor present to suggest some legitimacy and credibility around their policy (when I can easily find a doctor even more qualified who would have the exact opposite opinion on all of their 'policy'). When they started talking about 'religious exemptions' I had to drop from the call. 

When at the office now, I see signs for "Your safety is our number 1 concern". I don't give 2cents about your concern for my 'safety'; I'm perfectly capable of using my own judgement on that matter. Meanwhile it's very clear that Mastercard is clearly NOT concerned with my bodily autonomy and medical privacy. Will they soon be asking me for proof of 'booster number 12"?? What's awful is that the evidence is now abundant that these 'boosters' don't impact transmission. if someone wants to get the booster, that's their business; it's not mine and it's not Mastercard's.
